questions.text: Which of the following is not an inherited cancer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Inherited cancer syndromes:

  1. Familial retinoblastoma
  2. Familial adenomatous polyps of the colon
  3. Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes
  4. Neurofibromatosis types 1 and 2
  5. Von Hippel - Lindau syndrome

Familial cancers:

  1. Breast cancer
  2. Ovarian cancer
  3. Colonic cancer other than familial adenomatous polyps

Autosomal Recessive syndromes of Defective DNA Repair:

  1. Xeroderma pigmentosum
  2. Ataxia telangiectasia
  3. Bloom syndrome
  4. Fanconi anemia

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page Number-201.

questions.text: Characterize the tumour from the below figure:
questions.solution:
The tumour cells are strikingly similar to normal squamous epithelial cells, with intercellular bridges and nests of keratin (arrow).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 193.

questions.text: Name the occupational cancer caused by the agent-Benzene.
questions.solution: Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 198.

questions.text: The given figure shows:
questions.solution:
Cancer cells preferred to aerobic glycolysis than to oxidative phosphorylation to produce lactate.


WARBURG METABOLISM:

  • Warburg metabolism is a form of pro-growth metabolism favoring glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It is induced in normal cells by exposure to growth factors and becomes fixed in cancer cells due to the action of certain driver mutations.
  • Many oncoproteins(RAS, MYC, mutated growth factor receptors) induce or contribute to Warburg metabolism and many tumor suppressors(PTEN, NF1, p53) oppose it.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 217.

questions.text: Which of the following gene mutation is associated with Li Fraumeni syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Less commonly, patients inherit a mutant TP53 allele; the resulting disorder is called the Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • Patients with the Li-Fraumeni syndrome have a 25-fold greater chance of developing a malignant tumour by 50 years of age compared with the general population.
  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome(LFS) is a cancer predisposition syndrome associated with high risks for a diverse spectrum of childhood and adult-onset malignancies. The lifetime risk of cancer in individuals with LFS is ≥70% for men and ≥90% for women.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 211-212.

questions.text: Which of the following colour is imparted by the histochemical stain (triphenyltetrazolium chloride) in non-infarcted myocardium?
questions.solution:
Triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) is a histochemical stain that is used to identify viable myocardial tissue. In non-infarcted myocardium, TTC is reduced to triphenyltetrazolium formazan (TTF), which imparts a magenta color to the tissue.

  • Triphenyltetrazolium chloride differentiate between metabolically active and inactive tissues.
  • This histochemical stain has been employed in autopsy pathology to identify myocardial infarctions.

The other options are incorrect:

  • Black is the color of scar tissue.
  • Green is the color of healthy muscle tissue.
  • Yellow is the color of necrotic tissue.

TTC staining is a useful tool for diagnosing myocardial infarction and for assessing the extent of myocardial damage. It is also used in research studies to investigate the effects of different treatments on myocardial tissue.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg:49

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
In which of the following condition the cell can recover to its original state when the stress is eliminated?
i. Hypertrophy
ii. Hyperplasia
iii. Atrophy
iv. Metaplasia
questions.solution:
• Adaptation are reversible changes in the size, number, phenotype, metabolic activity, or functions of cells in response to changes in their environment.

CELLULAR ADAPTATIONS TO STRESS:

  • Hypertrophy: Increased cell and organ size, often in response to increased workload; induced by growth factors produced in response to mechanical stress or other stimuli; occurs in tissues incapable of cell division
  • Hyperplasia: Increased cell numbers in response to hormones and other growth factors; occurs in tissues whose cells are able to divide or contain abundant tissue stem cells.
  • Atrophy: Decreased cell and organ size, as a result of decreased nutrient supply or disuse, associated with decreased synthesis of cellular building blocks and increased breakdown of cellular organelles and autophagy.
  • Metaplasia: Change in phenotype of differentiated cells, often in response to chronic irritation, that makes cells better able to withstand the stress, usually induced by altered differentiation pathway of tissue stem cells. This may result in reduced functions or increased propensity for malignant transformation

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg:54

questions.text: Image shown is one of the initiation pathways of apoptosis. After initiation of this pathway; there is activation of caspase which triggers execution pathway of the apoptosis. Which of the following initiation caspase is activated by this pathway?
questions.solution:
• In mitochondrial pathway, after cytochrome c enters the cytosol, it together with certain cofactors, activates caspase-9.
  • The net result is the activation of a caspase cascade, ultimately leading to nuclear fragmentation and formation of apoptotic bodies.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg: 39

questions.text: In Neutrophil Extracellular Traps(NET) formation, arginine deaminase converts Arginine to:
questions.solution:
In Neutrophil Extracellular Traps(NET) formation, arginine deaminase converts Arginine to citrulline leading to chromatin condensation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg: 83

choices.text: The C3b breakdown product of complement

questions.text: Following is/are major opsonin(s) required for opsonization of microbes EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The efficiency of phagocytosis is greatly enhanced when microbes are opsonized(coated) by specific proteins(opsonins) for which the phagocytes express high-affinity receptors.
  • The major opsonins are immunoglobulin(Ig)G antibodies, the C3b breakdown product of complement activation and certain plasma lectins, notably mannose-binding lectin, all of which are recognized by specific receptors on leukocytes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 67.

questions.text: Match the Diseases Caused by Inflammatory Reactions
questions.solution:
Neutrophils are culprits in ARDS, Asthma predominantly has eosinophils, cytokines mediate septic shock, arthrits is due to lymphocytes and atherosclerosis have macrophages

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition, chapter 3, pg 71

questions.text: A 70-year-old male dies of an acute ischemic stroke. During the autopsy an incidental lesion is found in the apex of the right upper lobe of the lung. Microscopy reveals abundant macrophages with indistinct cell boundaries, surrounded by a rim of lymphocytes and a central zone of necrotic debris. Of the following, which is the most likely cause of this patient's lung lesion?
questions.solution:
Tb granuloma has characteristic feature of layering of lymphocytes outside. If no lymphocytes are present are on outside it is called naked granuloma seen in sarcoidosis.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition, chapter 3, pg 96

questions.text: Which cell produce antibodies required for humoral immunity?
questions.solution:
• There are two types of adaptive immunity.
  • Humoral immunity is mediated by soluble proteins called antibodies that are produced by B lymphocytes(also called B cells).
  • Cell-mediated(or cellular) immunity is mediated by T lymphocytes(also called T cells).
  • Humoral immunity is the aspect of immunity that is mediated by macromolecules - including secreted antibodies, complement proteins and certain antimicrobial peptides - located in extracellular fluids. Humoral immunity is named so because it involves substances found in the humors or body fluids.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 124.

questions.text: Macrophage engulfs different cells as shown in the image, the process is called:
questions.solution:
Emperipolesis is the active penetration of one cell by another which remains intact. It differs from phagocytosis in that an engulfed cell exists temporarily within another cell and with an intact normal structure while in phagocytosis, the engulfed cell is destroyed by the protective action of lysosomal enzymes. Extensive emperipolesis is seen in rosai dorfmann disease.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition, Chapter - 6, pg 200

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has a history of progressive developmental delay, ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter since infancy. The child has a normal karyotype of 46,XY, but DNA analysis shows that he has inherited both of his number 15 chromosomes from his father. These findings are most likely to be indicative of which of the following genetic mechanisms?
questions.solution:
This child has features of Angelman syndrome, and the DNA analysis shows uniparental disomy. The Angelman gene encoded on chromosome 15 is subject to genomic imprinting. It is silenced on the paternal chromosome 15, but is active on the maternal chromosome 15. If the child lacks maternal chromosome 15, there is no active Angelman gene in the somatic cells. This gives rise to the abnormalities typical of this disorder. The same effect occurs when there is a deletion of the Angelman gene from the maternal chromosome 15. The other listed options do not occur in uniparental disomy.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology 10th ed/ pg 271

questions.text: Fragile X syndrome is characterized by all Except:
questions.solution:
• Fragile X syndrome is the prototype of diseases in which the causative mutation occurs in a long repeating sequence of three nucleotides.
  • Fragile X syndrome results from a mutation in the FMR1 gene, which maps to Xq27.3 and is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation, after Down syndrome.
  • The typical physical phenotype includes a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears and large testicles(macroorchidism).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg: 269

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance is:
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial inheritance: The inheritance of a trait encoded in the mitochondrial genome. Because of the oddities of mitochondria, mitochondrial inheritance does not obey the classic rules of genetics.

  • Persons with a mitochondrial disease may be male or female but they are always related in the maternal line and no male with the disease can transmit it to his children. This is because ova contains multiple mitochondria, whereas spermatozoa contains few, hence, the mitochondrial content of zygote is derived almost entirely from ova.

Reference: Robbins basic pathology, 10th ed, Pg: 14

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient who is drug abuser presented with chief complaints of gradually increasing swelling over the leg and puffiness of face. Investigations revealed hematuria, mild hypertension. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. Renal biopsy performed shown below, based on the histological features what is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Crescents are formed by proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents.
  • By light microscopy, the glomeruli either appear normal in the early stages of the disease or exhibit uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall.
  • By light microscopy, the focal and segmental lesions may involve only a minority of the glomeruli and may be missed, if the biopsy specimen contains an insufficient number of glomeruli. In the sclerotic segments, there is collapse of capillary loops, increase in matrix, and segmental deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis), which may become so pronounced as to occlude capillary lumens.
  • In classic MPGN histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed pg. 915

questions.text: A molecular biologist was analysing the tumor cell, for which he was doing sanger sequencing. which methology best describes sanger sequencing
questions.solution:
Sequence the entire chromosome/gene

There are 2 ways:

  1. Sanger sequencing (old)
  2. NGS: Next generation sequencing (New)

Sanger is based on chain termination with dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs)

Adapter molecules are used in NGS

Reference: robbins pg 190
